Congressman Scott Perry offered the following statement after Republican House Leadership postponed the vote for the American Health Care Act, the Republican alternative to the Affordable Care Act:  “I ran on repealing the Affordable Care Act (ACA) - or “Obamacare” – not two-thirds of it, but the entire thing. The replacement bill - the American Health Care Act, as currently written - repeals the individual mandate and the employer mandate, but fails to end government control of personal health care. The fundamental problem with the ACA was the government takeover of personal health care decisions. Until we address that key point, we’ll never get to the root of the issue of rising costs and providing people with greater choice and flexibility in their health care coverage. During my four years in Congress, more people than I can count have told me – repeatedly – that they can’t afford health care. We simply must get costs down, and that starts with removing one-size-fits-all federal mandates. Instead of trying to get this done quickly, let’s get it done right. I’ll continue to work with the President and my House colleagues to get a reasonable proposal through the House to repeal the ACA once and for all.”

Last fall, local officials in all four counties I serve alerted me to a proposed rule from the U.S. Department of Transportation that would hurt the ability of local communities to best address their transportation needs. The rule would’ve mandated a one-size-fit-all federal solution to transportation planning, despite clear proof that local officials (especially here in the 4th District) are already working together to address these issues. It was a solution in search of a problem. Today, I joined my colleagues from both sides of the aisle on the House Transportation and Infrastructure Committee to repeal this unnecessary regulation. The Senate passed a similar bill earlier this month. I’ll fight to ensure it gets a vote by the full House and makes it to the President’s desk for signature.   https://transportation.house.gov/news/documentsingle.aspx?DocumentID=401278

On this day in history in 1787, we mark the beginning of the Constitutional Convention in Philadelphia, which ultimately brought an end to the Articles of Confederation and birthed the United States Constitution. The Articles of Confederation were the tenets that established the federal government following the end of the Revolutionary War, but were plagued with practical problems that posed numerous challenges for our fledgling Nation. To remedy these issues, our Founding Fathers called for the Convention. The Constitution, which governs us today, is still on display at the National Archives in Washington, D.C. To learn more visit https://www.archives.gov/museum/.

Today, June 6, marks the 73rd Anniversary of D-Day – the massive, 160,000 Allied Troop invasion into Nazi-occupied France during World War II onto a heavily fortified beach in Normandy. Congressman Scott Perry offered the following response to President Trump’s recently unveiled budget proposal:  “A president’s budget is always a starting point for discussion; Congress ultimately is responsible for setting spending levels. Any budget must balance protections for the taxpayer and those who are most vulnerable. While some of President Trump's budget requests fail to address key drivers of our $20 trillion debt and focus only on a small portion of the federal budget, he deserves great credit for submitting a balanced budget and prioritizing both the national debt and the annual deficits. His budget is projected to reduce deficits by $5.6 trillion over a ten-year period, resulting in a $16 billion surplus, and it drops our national debt from 77.4 percent of gross domestic product (GDP) this year to 59.8 percent by the end of the same time period. Despite the narrative being pushed elsewhere, the vast majority of programs impacted by this budget will see only a reduction in their rate of future growth - they’re not actually being cut. I’m hopeful that we can find common ground during the budget process and finally get serious about controlling federal spending.”

Representative Scott Perry (R-PA) offered the following statement in reaction to the Congressional Budget Office assessment of the American Health Care Act (AHCA):   “I’ve said from the beginning that this legislation is imperfect, and doesn’t go far enough to end the Affordable Care Act, but inaction wasn’t – and still isn’t – an option. The failed policies of the ACA are driving up the costs of both health care and medical insurance nationwide and the pace is unsustainable. A new Health and Human Services report shows that since 2013, premiums have increased on average nationwide by 105%. The CBO originally predicted that 21 million Americans would have ACA coverage in 2016; yet only about 10.4 million actually gained coverage. To avoid the ACA entirely, more than 19 million people either paid the penalty or claimed an exemption from the individual mandate. This new CBO report also confirms that the American Health Care Act lowers premiums and the deficit. Regardless, the Senate is working on its own bill, which will receive a new CBO score, and then we’ll conference an agreement with yet another CBO score – so this process has a long way to play out.”

Today, in 1782, General George Washington, Commander in Chief of the Continental Army, created the “Badge for Military Merit” - known today as the Purple Heart. While the medal fell out of use shortly after the American Revolution, it was reinstated following the Japanese attack on Pearl Harbor during World War II. Since then, roughly 1.8 million Purple Hearts have been awarded to U.S. Service Members, and posthumously to their Families, in recognition of wounds or loss of life during a military engagement. On this day in 1920, the 19th Amendment was certified by U.S. Secretary of State Bainbridge Colby. The 19th Amendment gave women the right to vote in elections nationwide, ending a patchwork of laws by individual states. In certain counties in Pennsylvania, including those represented in the 4th Congressional District, women were allowed to vote throughout the 1910s. Even so, a statewide referendum to ensure the right to vote across the Commonwealth was defeated in 1915. Not until five years later, when Pennsylvania became the 7th state in the Nation to ratify the 19th Amendment, would the franchise be granted for all women over the age of 21. To learn more about the Women’s Suffrage movement visit, https://www.si.edu/spotlight/womens-suffrage.

As Central Pennsylvania gears up to see the first coast-to-coast Solar Eclipse in the US in 99 years, I share some basic safety tips from our friends at NASA - National Aeronautics and Space Administration.   1. The only safe way to look directly at the uneclipsed or partially eclipsed sun is through special-purpose solar filters, such as “eclipse glasses” or hand-held solar viewers. Homemade filters or ordinary sunglasses, even very dark ones, aren't safe for looking at the sun; they transmit thousands of times too much sunlight.   2. Don't look at the uneclipsed / partially eclipsed sun through an unfiltered camera, telescope, binoculars or other optical device. 3. Always supervise children using solar filters.   For more safety information, visit:  https://eclipse2017.nasa.gov/safety.

Last week, I supported legislation in the House to provide $7.85 billion in aid for the victims of Hurricane Harvey – the first of what’s expected to be a series of relief proposals in the wake of recent disasters. Growing up, we were flooded out of our home twice by severe storms, and I’ve seen the impact of other natural disasters on my own community.  I’m well aware it could happen again.  This issue deserved a vote on its own merits and I would’ve gladly supported it again; but the Senate attached several unrelated policy items to the bill that forced me to vote against the final package.  One of these items was an increase to our debt ceiling – which was provided without any corresponding spending cuts or other mechanisms to rein in our existing $20 trillion debt. I was hoping we could come together to have an open and honest discussion about how to address this crisis; instead, we again punted it down the road. As our debt continues to grow, we limit our Nation’s ability to respond to tragedies like Hurricanes Harvey and Irma – in addition to a host of other direct and related problems. We ignore this growing crisis at our Nation’s peril.

President Donald J. Trump has a responsibility to the American People to ensure the security of the United States. As promised, the Administration has reviewed security protocols for entry into the United States and is adjusting these policies, which includes setting baseline security standards for entry into the country. Most countries already meet these standards, but roughly 9 nations do not. The U.S. is providing those countries with approximately 50 days to develop a plan for compliance. The travel restrictions also contain notable exceptions, including legal permanent residents, dual nationals, diplomats, foreign nationals previously granted asylum, some student visas and any refugee previously admitted to the U.S. from any of the impacted countries. The pause is also expanded to include Chad, North Korea and Venezuela. This is a measured, common sense approach that strikes a balance between security and liberty, while putting the needs of our citizens first. You can learn more about these efforts here: https://www.whitehouse.gov/the-press-office/2017/09/24/president-donald-j-trump-announces-enhanced-national-security-measures

You may have heard some recent media about me with regard to my votes and comments about aid to Puerto Rico that, apparently, need clarification.  I appreciate the opportunity.    Growing up, my family’s home was twice devastated by severe storms and flood. Throughout my military career, I’ve been involved with numerous emergency, disaster and humanitarian relief efforts here in the United States and abroad. I’ve seen firsthand the devastation and human suffering caused by these events. I also spent most of my childhood in poverty and know what it’s like to be forced to build a life without having much to build it with.   According to FEMA, more than $53 million has been sent to citizens in Puerto Rico, and more than $169 million for emergency work thus far. FEMA, working in coordination with other federal partners, has provided Puerto Rico with more than 7 million meals and 6 million liters of water to date. The U.S. is working around the clock to bring relief and to restore power, communications and water to Puerto Rico. FEMA, by design, is intended for disaster response and emergency management; they’re not capable of, nor are they equipped for rebuild and restructure missions.  In addition, other disasters/response missions are occurring simultaneously to which FEMA also must respond. I greatly appreciate and support all of these efforts.    Late this week, the House considered a $35 billion aid proposal; it included unrelated policy provisions that would’ve failed if considered individually, and it wasn’t even open to amendment or debate.  It’s unacceptable in a time of crisis for Congress to exploit the desperation of disaster victims.  I didn’t support the proposal. I support aid for Puerto Rico because I want to help mitigate the unimaginable suffering being endured by our fellow citizens; but we must make decisions of this magnitude in an open and transparent manner. Blindly dispersing tens of billions of dollars without public debate and tacking on unrelated items for political expediency is not only wrong, it’s not effective or fair to anyone.  We all wish this process could work faster. In its incessant desire to oppose everything that President Trump says or does, however, CNN attacked our response to the Puerto Rico crisis and alleged that we care more about Texas’ and Florida’s victims. The allegations were ridiculous and insulting, and I wasn’t about to let those comments go unchallenged. The exchange may have become heated, but it doesn’t change the fact that my life experiences have given me great empathy for the people of Puerto Rico and the loss and suffering they’re enduring.  As I’ve seen with my own eyes with natural disasters of this scale, federal resources are strained. The devastation is unprecedented and FEMA is spread thin confronting other disasters as well. Although we don’t have unlimited resources, we should do what it takes to ensure that our fellow citizens have the resources they need to recover and rebuild. Needlessly politicizing the issue for ratings and partisan gain is reprehensible and, most importantly, helps no one.

Over the course of the last few weeks, I’ve heard from constituents from across the political spectrum about the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, the GOP Tax Plan. No one should ever be forced by the Government to purchase a product or service because it directly contradicts the fundamental notion of American liberty enshrined in the U.S. Constitution. That’s why I’m proud to announce the GOP Tax Plan repeals the individual mandate established in the Affordable Care Act / Obamacare. We need to stop forcing people to buy something they don’t want, can’t afford or don’t need - and instead empower individuals to make the choices that are best for them and their families.

Did you know the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act expands the Child Tax Credit up to $2,000 per child? The tax credit is fully refundable up to $1,400. A refundable tax credit means you get to count the credit amount toward your liability (how much you owe the federal government), and then get extra money back if the credit is more than what you owe for taxes. It can mean that you and your family get money back from the federal government that you didn’t pay in. The bill also preserves the Adoption Tax Credit and the Dependent tax credit for families who help take care of an elderly parent or an adult child who is disabled.
